CatDescriptText: Mrs. Mamie Murphy, hotel worker, Fifth Ward and Mr. William Coyne, artist, North Side, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column, published in the Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 29, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think that laws should be made and enforced to eliminate segregation and discrimination, or should education and "moral persuasion" be used instead?"  Mrs. Murphy's answer reads: "I think that education is the best thing because both white and colored children are not used to mixing."  Mr. Coyne's answer reads: "I don't think that laws are the right thing.  This has to come about naturally, therefore the best way is through education."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Mamie Murphy wearing light colored print patterned short sleeve shirt, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of William Coyne wearing diagonally striped necktie and suit jacket, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
